TextBody:
Dear Bogdan,

I have received a response from our legal team, can you please fill in the attached addendum "Netwrix_EPP Virtual appliance access addendum_Template.docx" and return it with your signature please?


Kind regards
__________________
André Le Roux | Technical Support Engineer

Subject: RE: Netwrix Support Ticket #436756 - - Default TLS certificates replacing [ ref:!00D70091pB.!500Qk0MEc0j:ref ]

Dear Bogdan,

Thank you for your response.  I will forward your request to management and then get back to you with a response.


Kind regards

--------------- Original Message ---------------
From: Bogdan Panasiuk [b.panasiuk@fhl.world]
Sent: 2/28/2025 8:07 PM
To: techsupport@netwrix.com
Subject: RE: Netwrix Support Ticket #436756 - - Default TLS certificates replacing [ ref:!00D70091pB.!500Qk0MEc0j:ref ]

ref:_00D7091pB._500Q000MEc0j:ref



Dear André

 

I appreciate your assistance in resolving this matter.


	Do you want to receive access to your EPP server backend ?

	
		Yes, we do.
	
	
	Can you please confirm why you need SSH access to the server?
	
		In our company, we try to automate as many routine tasks as possible. Using Certbot will help automate periodic TLS certificate renewal.
	
	
	What are you trying to achieve with this access?
	
		Automating routine tasks makes it easier to maintain information systems and helps minimize the impact of human error. Timely replacement of TLS certificates will help prevent data loss from agents.
	
	
	Could you please provide us more details regarding this case?
	
		We want to install Certbot and the Certbot plugin for AWS Route 53 on the Netwrix Endpoint Protector Server (an EC2 instance in our AWS account). This tool should connect to AWS Route 53 to create a new TLS certificate and replace the old one. A cron job (the system daemon for scheduling tasks on Linux operating systems) will be used to run the utility periodically. More details about the installation and usage of these utilities are described in this article -  https://timamtalukdar.medium.com/lets-encrypt-wildcard-certificate-route53-nginx-centos-rhel-7-27922b406557
	
	


Thank you in advance.

 

Best Regards,

 

Bogdan Panasiuk

IT Security manager

Email: b.panasiuk@fhl.world

 

 

 



From: Netwrix Support <techsupport@netwrix.com>
Sent: Friday, February 28, 2025 5:18 PM
To: Bogdan Panasiuk <b.panasiuk@fhl.world>
Subject: RE: Netwrix Support Ticket #436756 - - Default TLS certificates replacing [ ref:!00D70091pB.!500Qk0MEc0j:ref ]



 


	
		
			
			
			External email 
			
			
		
	


 


Dear Bogdan,

I have discussed your request / requirement internally. 

We can provide you with a secondary account (your own credentials) for SSH root access to the backend of the Endpoint Protector Server Appliance.  However when we provide you with your own root credentials you will need to perform the procedure yourself as this will not be within our support scope.  The changes that you will then make are changes that we did not test with our product.  We will not be held liable in case anything goes wrong and negatively impacts your Endpoint Protector Server Appliance.

If you wish to proceed then a request can be made to obtain your own root credentials but this will need to be qualified by our legal department.  A legal document (agreement) will need to be signed by Netwrix and by the representative of your organization, when this request has been approved by our legal team then only can we create your own root user however to do this we will need to access the backend of your EPP Server at least once to create your own root user.

In your response could you also provide us with the answers to the below questions that our Legal department will require please?


	Do you want to receive access to your EPP server backend ?
	Can you please confirm why you need SSH access to the server?
	What are you trying to achieve with this access?
	Could you please provide us more details regarding this case?



Kind regards
__________________
André Le Roux | Technical Support Engineer
Endpoint Protector by CoSoSys, now part of Netwrix
DLP | Device Control | Content Aware Protection | eDiscovery | Enforced Encryption
www.endpointprotector.com

This Email may contain confidential information. Not to be disclosed to third parties without prior written approval.

Also, there was a question in a past email that I didn't get an answer to. 

Are we allowed to make changes inside an EC2 Netwrix sever instance?

 

 

Best Regards,

 

Bogdan Panasiuk

Sent: Tuesday, February 25, 2025 1:53 PM

Subject: RE: Netwrix Support Ticket #436756 - - Default TLS certificates replacing [ ref:!00D70091pB.!500Qk0MEc0j:ref ]



 


	
		
			
			
			External email 
			
			
		
	


 


Hi Bogdan,

Thank you for your response.  Currently we do not yet have the functionality to enable automatic SSL certificate renewal via integration or directly from the Cososys Endpoint Protector console.  The manual way is the only current way of rotating certificates, however we would like to know if you would like us to raise this as a potential improvement suggestion to PM for the future?


Kind regards
__________________
André Le Roux | Technical Support Engineer
Endpoint Protector by CoSoSys, now part of Netwrix

From: Bogdan Panasiuk [b.panasiuk@fhl.world]
Sent: 2/25/2025 12:39 PM
To: techsupport@netwrix.com
Subject: RE: Netwrix Support Ticket #436756 - ref:_00D7091pB._500Q000MEc0j:ref - Default TLS certificates replacing [ ref:!00D70091pB.!500Qk0MEc0j:ref ]

ref:_00D7091pB._500Q000MEc0j:ref

 


Thanks for the information!

 

Our DevOps team also suggests configuring Certbot with a plugin for AWS Route53. (https://timamtalukdar.medium.com/lets-encrypt-wildcard-certificate-route53-nginx-centos-rhel-7-27922b406557). We use this software to automate certificate rotation.

 

Can we go into the Netwrix EC2 server instance system shell (using AWS SSM) and make the necessary configuration changes?

 

 

Best Regards,

 

Bogdan Panasiuk

IT Security manager

Email: b.panasiuk@fhl.world

 

 

 

 



From: Netwrix Support <techsupport@netwrix.com>
Sent: Monday, February 24, 2025 7:15 PM
To: Bogdan Panasiuk <b.panasiuk@fhl.world>
Subject: Default TLS certificates replacing [ ref:!00D70091pB.!500Qk0MEc0j:ref ]



 


	
		
			
			
			External email 
			
			
		
	


 


Dear Bogdan,

Thank you for contacting Netwrix Support support.

You can import your own certificate under "Appliance" > " Server Maintenance". This will allow for secured connection between the end computer and the EPP Server UI.




I hope this information helps, please do let me know if you have any follow up questions.

Kind regards
__________________
André Le Roux | Technical Support Engineer

  1.  What are you trying to achieve with this access?

     *   Automating routine tasks makes it easier to maintain information systems and helps minimize the impact of human error. Timely replacement of TLS certificates will help prevent data loss from agents.

  1.  Could you please provide us more details regarding this case?

This tool should connect to AWS Route 53 to create a new TLS certificate and replace the old one. A cron job (the system daemon for scheduling tasks on Linux operating systems) will be used to run the utility periodically. More details about the installation and usage of these utilities are described in this article - https://timamtalukdar.medium.com/lets-encrypt-wildcard-certificate-route53-nginx-centos-rhel-7-27922b406557

TextBody:
Hello Bogdan,

Thank you for your email. Unfortunately custom configurations to the nginx is not within our support scope.   The only time that we do configure the nginx is when the customer wants to do port separation between the EPP Server UI and the client to server communication.

Kind regards
__________________

From: Bogdan Panasiuk [b.panasiuk@fhl.world]
Sent: 2/28/2025 8:07 PM
To: techsupport@netwrix.com
Subject: RE: Netwrix Support Ticket #436756 - - Default TLS certificates replacing [ ref:!00D70091pB.!500Qk0MEc0j:ref ]

ref:_00D7091pB._500Q000MEc0j:ref

 


Dear André

 

I appreciate your assistance in resolving this matter.


	Do you want to receive access to your EPP server backend ?



	
	
		Yes, we do.
	
	



	Can you please confirm why you need SSH access to the server?



	
	
		In our company, we try to automate as many routine tasks as possible. Using Certbot will help automate periodic TLS certificate renewal.
	
	



	What are you trying to achieve with this access?



	
	
		Automating routine tasks makes it easier to maintain information systems and helps minimize the impact of human error. Timely replacement of TLS certificates will help prevent data loss from agents.
	
	



	Could you please provide us more details regarding this case?



	
	
		We want to install Certbot and the Certbot plugin for AWS Route 53 on the Netwrix Endpoint Protector Server (an EC2 instance in our AWS account). This tool should connect to AWS Route 53 to create a new TLS certificate and replace the old one. A cron job (the system daemon for scheduling tasks on Linux operating systems) will be used to run the utility periodically. More details about the installation and usage of these utilities are described in this article -  https://timamtalukdar.medium.com/lets-encrypt-wildcard-certificate-route53-nginx-centos-rhel-7-27922b406557
	
	


Thank you in advance.

 

Best Regards,

 

Bogdan Panasiuk

IT Security manager

Email: b.panasiuk@fhl.world

 

 

 



From: Netwrix Support <techsupport@netwrix.com>
Sent: Friday, February 28, 2025 5:18 PM
To: Bogdan Panasiuk <b.panasiuk@fhl.world>
Subject: RE: Netwrix Support Ticket #436756 - - Default TLS certificates replacing [ ref:!00D70091pB.!500Qk0MEc0j:ref ]



 


	
		
			
			
			External email 
			
			
		
	


 


Dear Bogdan,

I have discussed your request / requirement internally. 

We can provide you with a secondary account (your own credentials) for SSH root access to the backend of the Endpoint Protector Server Appliance.  However when we provide you with your own root credentials you will need to perform the procedure yourself as this will not be within our support scope.  The changes that you will then make are changes that we did not test with our product.  We will not be held liable in case anything goes wrong and negatively impacts your Endpoint Protector Server Appliance.

If you wish to proceed then a request can be made to obtain your own root credentials but this will need to be qualified by our legal department.  A legal document (agreement) will need to be signed by Netwrix and by the representative of your organization, when this request has been approved by our legal team then only can we create your own root user however to do this we will need to access the backend of your EPP Server at least once to create your own root user.

In your response could you also provide us with the answers to the below questions that our Legal department will require please?


	Do you want to receive access to your EPP server backend ?
	Can you please confirm why you need SSH access to the server?
	What are you trying to achieve with this access?
	Could you please provide us more details regarding this case?



Kind regards
__________________
André Le Roux | Technical Support Engineer
Endpoint Protector by CoSoSys, now part of Netwrix
DLP | Device Control | Content Aware Protection | eDiscovery | Enforced Encryption
www.endpointprotector.com

This tool should connect to AWS Route 53 to create a new TLS certificate and replace the old one. A cron job (the system daemon for scheduling tasks on Linux operating systems) will be used to run the utility periodically.
